title: When to Sell vs Hold: Practical Factors for Bottle Owners
metaTitle: When to Sell Your Wine Collection vs Hold | Proof Cellars
metaDescription: Is now the right time to sell? Learn how to evaluate storage costs, consumption maturity, and market cycles for your collection.
summary: A non-investment guide to timing decisions based on storage risk, liquidity needs, and hassle.

sections.heading: Quick Answer
content: Wine is a depreciating asset if not stored perfectly. Sell if you are no longer drinking it or if storage costs exceed appreciation.
list: Sell When: You are downsizing, the wine is at peak maturity, or you need liquidity.
Hold When: The wine is too young (needs 10+ years), or it has huge sentimental value.

sections.heading: The Cost of Holding
list: Over 10 years, that is $18,000 in storage fees.
Does the wine appreciate enough to cover that? Often no.

sections.heading: Peak Maturity
list: Most Napa Cabs peak at age 10-15.
If you hold past the peak, the value drops to zero (unsellable 'over the hill' wine).
It is better to sell 5 years too early than 1 year too late.

sections.heading: Market Cycles
list: We are currently in a high demand cycle for Burgundy and Bourbon.
Bordeaux prices have been stable but flat.

sections.heading: Common Mistakes
content: Waiting for a 'special occasion' that never comes.
list: Dying with a cellar full of 1982 Bordeaux because 'it wasn't the right time'.
Assuming wine always goes up in value (it doesn't).
Breaking a full case to drink one bottle (devalues the remaining 11).

sections.heading: What to Do Next
list: Identify wines that are 'ready ot drink' now.
If you have more than you can drink in 5 years, sell the excess.
Get a valuation to see what your 'liquid assets' are actually worth.

faqs.question: Does wine always go up?
faqs.answer: No. Like stocks, it can crash. And unlike stocks, it can turn into vinegar.

faqs.question: Is whiskey a better investment?
faqs.answer: Whiskey doesn't spoil in the bottle, so it is safer to hold long term. But markets still fluctuate.

faqs.question: Can I sell just half?
faqs.answer: Yes! We often buy 'half the cellar'â€”the bottles the owner knows they won't drink.

faqs.question: What if labels are damaged?
faqs.answer: Sell sooner rather than later. Damage gets worse with time (mold grows).

faqs.question: Do you buy young wine?
faqs.answer: Yes, we buy current releases too (often from people who over-bought on mailing lists).
